Geom

This college-preparatory course in Euclidean Geometry develops a solid background in geometric skills and ideas and also places a significant emphasis on mathematical thinking. There is a special stress on processes such as finding patterns, investigating, making conjectures, developing appropriate habits of mind, explaining one’s results, making connections, argument, and proof. This approach is based on the premise that the best way to prepare students to solve problems that don’t yet exist is to help them develop the ways of thinking that are characteristic of mathematics and science. The approach stresses depth rather than breadth, often presenting long problems that extend throughout an entire class period or even more than one class period.

Syllabus

This college-preparatory course in Euclidean Geometry uses the textbook Geometry for Enjoyment and Challenge. This program not only develops a solid background in geometric skills and ideas but also places a significant emphasis on mathematical thinking, inquiry, and exploration. There is a special stress on processes such as finding patterns, investigating, making conjectures, developing appropriate habits of mind, explaining one’s results, making connections, argument, and proof. This approach is based on the premise that the best way to prepare students to solve problems that don’t yet exist is to help them develop the ways of thinking that are characteristic of mathematics and science.” The approach stresses depth rather than breadth, often presenting long problems that extend throughout an entire class period or even more than one class period.

The year is divided into four major topics of unequal length:

  • invariance
  • congruence and proof
  • similarity and trigonometry
  • dissection, area, and volume

Topic 1, Invariance, has a dual purpose. Its mathematical content includes the basic concepts and skills of geometry, with a particular emphasis on geometric transformations. And its procedural content aims to help all students develop appropriate mathematical habits of mind. These dual goals give students a strong foundation for their subsequent work.

Geometric content in Topic 1 includes congruence-preserving transformations (translation, reflection, rotation); naming, defining, drawing, and constructing standard geometric shapes; parallels and perpendiculars; nets; symmetry; the Triangle Inequality; regions of lines, planes, and space; central and inscribed angles in circles; angles in triangles and other polygons; numerical and spatial invariants; and perpendicular bisectors, angle bisectors, and medians in triangles. Students study geometric transformations from a functional perspective and have opportunities to practice their algebra skills through equation-solving, matrices, and extensive use of coordinates.

The ten habits of mind that are stressed in Topic 1 are as follows:

  1. Picturing the visible, picturing the invisible.
  2. Analyzing and interpreting a figure
  3. Using precise language to describe and analyze (including names, features, and definitions)
  4. Tinkering with problems
  5. Mixing deduction with experimentation
  6. Looking for invariants
  7. Reasoning about processes
  8. Reasoning by continuity
  9. Proving
  10. Using different systems

Topic 2, Congruence and Proof, focuses on congruence but stresses proof as its major idea. Students learn to develop and present proofs after suitable investigation and experimentation. Geometric content includes congruence in general, congruent triangles, isometries, and further understanding of triangles and other polygons, including properties of quadrilaterals.

Topic 3, Similarity and Trigonometry, stresses scale drawing, similar figures, and right-triangle trigonometry. Students apply their algebra and strengthen their knowledge of ratio and proportion; they learn mathematical principles behind similar triangles; areas, volumes, and perimeters of similar figures; scaling and similarity transformations; pi and other concepts involved in working with circles; and use of the sine, cosine, and tangent ratios. All of these examples combine conceptual work and the detailed skills involved in finding correct answers. There are many applications to map-making, scale drawings and blueprints, navigation, biology, and indirect measurement.

Topic 4, Dissection, Area, and Volume, concentrates on area, perimeter, volume, and the Pythagorean Theorem, with a special emphasis on dissection as a tool for research and understanding. Although students continue to investigate and explore, this topic also stresses algorithmic thinking and improvement of visualization skills. Connections with algebra return in the context of numerical problems.

This course builds upon previous work in Algebra I and Geometry by pursuing algebraic ideas in greater depth and breadth. Topics and subtopics include systems of equations and inequalities of the first and second degrees; polynomial, exponential, logarithmic, and other functions in both explicit and recursive forms; the theory of functions, including function representations, inverses, composition, domain and range; matrices; transformations of graphs; an introduction to sequences, emphasizing explicit and recursive definitions; counting, probability, and combinatorics; and an introduction to statistics. Computer programming is introduced as a topic in itself and is used throughout the course, as are graphing calculators. There is a balance between mathematical theory and its application to many endeavors, particularly mathematical modeling, cryptography, linear programming, and game theory. In all these contexts, students are expected to develop and demonstrate skills and concepts at an honors level.

Syllabus

There are four major topics during the year:

Topic 1, Introduction to Abstract Algebra, sets the stage for the entire year. The class learns about sets, relations, binary operations, and functions. Functions are studied in many ways, as rules, machines, tables, mapping diagrams, and graphs. Composition of functions, inverses of functions, transformations of graphs, and recursive vs. explicit definitions are all examined. Students learn the properties of specific functions and function families, both continuous and discrete, with an emphasis on exponential and logarithmic functions. Students are introduced to the use of graphing calculators, to a powerful piece of mathematical software called MAPLE ,and to computer programming in a language called Scheme. This topic includes applications to mathematical modeling, especially for situations involving exponential growth and decay.

Topic 2, Statistics, starts with a brief review of students' prior experience with data analysis from Middle School ( including measures of center, such as mean, median, and mode ) and then proceeds to extend those ideas to measures of spread, such as range, variance, and standard deviation. The idea of a distribution of data is emphasized. Students will develop models to fit both linear and non-linear relationships between two variables, with emphasis on ordinary least squares methods.

Topic 3, Introduction to Number Theory, starts with primes, composites, the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, factoring, divisors, greatest common divisor, and least common multiples. Modular arithmetic and the algebra of congruences is developed, and this leads to the principal application of this topic, an extensive exploration of cryptology. This application includes a function-based approach to cryptography using classical ciphers such as substitution and Vigenere, modern encryption with matrices and RSA, and a touch of cryptanalysis.

Topic 4, Introduction to Probability, includes systematic counting, combinations and permutations, the definition of probability, the multiplication principle, binomial probability, the binomial theorem, and conditional probability. Applications may include genetics, detection of fraud, meedical testing, and manufacturing quality control.

Syllabus

This course builds upon previously studied topics from Algebra I and Geometry. It develops skills and emphasizes applications of those skills. Topics of Study

The college-prep Algebra II course is divided into four major units of roughly equal length:

Supplies

You will need the following supplies, which you should have with you in class every day and otherwise available when you are doing your math work:

A stapler, a hole punch, and a computer will also be helpful at home.

Classwork and Homework

Work will be assigned on a regular basis. There is no distinction between classwork and homework. If you get it done in class, just consider it classwork; if you don’t, then you’ll need to finish it as homework. It is your responsibility to check westonmath.org every day to find out what work is due when. If no work seems to be posted, check with your teacher to see whether there is actually an assignment! To receive full credit, you must have your completed assignment with you at the beginning of class on the day on which it is due. You must also show your work for all problems, even when you were not successful. If you can’t solve a problem, record your attempts. Homework will be evaluated based on the quality and effort of the end product.

Sometimes we will not discuss work on the day when it is due, and sometimes we will refer back to previous assignments, so it is important for you to hold onto back work from day to day. Since you will be doing all your work in your bound lab notebook, you will have no trouble holding onto it.

Late work may be accepted for partial credit if you hand it in by the beginning of the next class after it was due, provided it shows sincere effort and full work on all problems.

Do your work carefully and promptly in your bound lab notebook. Include the date, your name, and the assignment number. Write the entire problem down, or at least show enough of it so that you and the teacher can tell what the problem was! Don’t crowd your work. When you have a handout — or you’ve printed out your own copy of an assignment — you should treat it as a list of questions, not as a location for writing your solutions. Sometimes your work will be looked at in class, sometimes your lab notebook will be collected, and sometimes we will discuss it without checking it. You won’t know in advance, so you should always do a thorough job.

In all cases you must show your work! It’s the process that will be of value to you: you’re extremely unlikely to come across the exact same problem again, so you need to be able to think and to communicate your thoughts.

Sometimes you’ll be unable to complete a solution. (Perhaps from time to time you’ll even feel unable to begin solving a problem successfully.) This lab-based course is intended for students who want to broaden and deepen their knowledge of computers in areas other than programming. Topics include the design and structure of databases and spreadsheets, the internal workings of computers, the history of computing, artificial intelligence, and how the Internet works.

Themes:

  1. Representing, storing, and retrieving data.
  2. Models for creating and accessing information.
  3. Communication within networks and computers.

Course Content:

In Unit 1 (Representing Data), students learn how to design and build databases and spreadsheets. Concepts include multiple representations of data, data types, fields, calculated fields, records, layouts, tables, relations, and scripts, as well as the similarities and differences between databases and spreadsheets. The fundamental question is how we can represent and access data as effectively as possible. Software applications include FileMaker, Excel, and MySQL.

In Unit 2 (Exploring the Internet), students learn how the Internet works so it no longer feels like magic. Concepts include the history of the Internet, the use of IP numbers and the domain name system, how email and webpages work, and construction of webpages using HTML and simple Javascript. The fundamental question is how information can get from my computer to your computer. Along the way, students explore some of the related social, economic, and ethical issues. Software applications include a variety of browsers and text editors.

In Unit 3 (Understanding Computers), students learn about the internals of computer hardware and software. The fundamental question is how a collection of silicon and circuits can lead all the way to sophisticated computer applications. Ideas include binary numbers, the basics of computer architecture, logic gates, an introduction to operating systems, and the problem of artificial intelligence.

Trigonometry and its applications, conic sections, polynomials, complex numbers and polar coordinates, sequences and series, limits, fractals, and mathematical induction are some of the topics studied. Students will use graphing calculators regularly in this course as well as a variety of computer software. This course is a recommended prerequisite for any student considering enrollment in AB or BC Calculus (Course 361 or 371).

Honors Precalculus deepens and broadens students’ previous mathematical work. Major topics include trigonometry and its applications, polynomials, complex numbers, polar coordinates, sequences and series, limits, fractals, and mathematical induction. Computer programming is integrated into the mathematical work throughout the course, as are graphing calculators. There is a careful balance between mathematical theory and its application to many endeavors, such as navigation, economics, fractals, chaos, and the physics of motion, light, and sound. In all these contexts, students are expected to work hard to develop and demonstrate skills and concepts at an honors level.

There are three major units during the year:

Unit 1 — Expanding Trigonometry — consists of four related modules:

  • The first module focuses on solving triangles, starting with a review of the trigonometry of right triangles and moving on to all triangles — with a point of view that considers sine, cosine, and tangent to be functions rather than mere ratios — including the Law of Cosines and Law of Sines.
  • The second module develops the trig functions as wrapping functions, develops the inverse trig functions, studies polar graphing, and explores sinusoidal modeling of real-world periodic phenomena, especially music.
  • The third module introduces the reciprocal trig functions and incorporates trigonometric equations and identities.
  • The fourth module applies trigonometry as it introduces complex numbers along with vectors and polar coordinates.

Unit 2 — Iteration and Recursion — explores many important ideas in mathematics. These range from the abstractions of mathematical induction to the practical applications of fractals and chaos theory. Sequences and iteration of functions are included in the unit.

Unit 3 — Polynomials & Numbers — deepens the students’ experience in algebra and uses it to make sense of our numeration system. Polynomial functions and conic sections have many implications both in mathematical theory and in applications, ranging from the binomial theorem to the physics of parabolic headlights and elliptical rooms. Sequences, series, sigma notation, rational functions, and limits of sequences are explored. The unit concludes with a study of limits of functions as an introduction to calculus.

Supplies

We recommend that you use a well-organized 3-ring binder for all class notes, homework, returned tests and quizzes, and handouts. If you wish to take notes in a spiral or perfect-bound notebook, you are welcome to do so — but you should still have a 3-ring binder for handouts and for material that has been returned to you. We have found that it is usually impossible to remain organized if you use folders for this purpose, but that’s up to you.

You will also need pencils, erasers, lined paper, graph paper, and a graphing calculator. You may use any graphing calculator, but the TI-83 (or TI-83 Plus or TI-84) is recommended and will be used for class demonstrations.

While you aren’t actually required to have a computer at home, you probably do have one. It will be extremely useful throughout the year, and will save you from needing to go to computer labs at school to do homework during or after the school day.

Homework

Homework is usually assigned four or five times in every eight-day cycle. To receive full credit, you must have your completed assignment with you at the beginning of class on the day on which it is due. You must also show detailed work for all problems, even when you were not successful. If you can’t solve a problem, record your attempts.

Working together on problems is allowed and encouraged. However, except in the most straightforward cases each student’s solution should look different, even when the answers are the same. Solutions that are identical may not be given credit. By this point you should know the difference between cooperation and cheating, and you should know how to work with others in an appropriate way without taking credit for their work. If you do work with someone else, it is essential that you clearly indicate the name of the person(s) with whom you worked.

Late homework will be accepted for half-credit if you hand it in by the beginning of the next class after the one when it was due — provided it shows sincere effort and full work on all problems.

Do your homework carefully and promptly. Include the date, your name, and the assignment number. (This sounds trivial, but it isn’t. Without assignment numbers, it is difficult or impossible to find earlier assignments when it’s necessary to refer to them.) Write the entire problem down, or at least show enough of it so you, your classmates, and your teacher can tell what the problem was!

Don’t crowd your work. When you have a handout, or you’ve printed out your own copy of an assignment, you should treat that merely as a list of questions, not as a location for writing your solutions, except where ample space has been provided for your work! Write the solutions on a separate sheet of paper that you are prepared to hand in, and then keep it in your notebook. Always do a thorough job. Sincere effort on homework assignments is, of course, essential to success in any course.

In all cases you must show your work! Answers are a penny a pound — essentially worthless. It’s only the process that will be of value to you: you’re extremely unlikely to come across the exact same problem again, so you need to be able to think and to communicate your thoughts.

Sometimes you’ll be unable to complete a solution. (Perhaps from time to time you’ll even feel unable to begin solving a problem successfully.) In such cases you still need to communicate your thoughts and your attempts; your teacher won’t want to see big white spaces instead of a solution. Come to class with a clear list of any questions you have about the homework problems; they may or may not be answered right away, so be sure that you can still find the list on subsequent days.

Tests & Quizzes

All tests will be announced well in advance, so you will have time to study. Each test will contain one part in which you may use both your calculator and a 3"-by-5" notecard, followed by a calculator-free and note-free part.

Quizzes will not be announced in advance, but you may usually use notes when taking a quiz. Calculators may or may not be allowed on quizzes, depending on the subject matter.

You will receive two grades on each test or quiz: a raw score and an adjusted score. Adjusted scores are made by assessment of competence, not by arbitrary scaling or grading on a curve. Excellent work earns a 90 or higher, competent work an 80 or higher.

To earn an adjusted score of 90 or higher on a test or quiz, you must do an excellent job the first time you take it. But you can have a second chance to earn an 83 by learning the material later in the term. If you get below an adjusted score of 83 on a test or quiz, you are considered to have “not yet earned a B.” You will have the opportunity — which you are strongly urged to accept! — to relearn any material on which you were not yet competent. You have two ways in which you may subsequently demonstrate your newly acquired competence:

  • successfully solving problems on the next regularly scheduled test if it covers the same skills and concepts as the quiz on which you earned below a B, or
  • meeting with your teacher to show that you have relearned the material, and then scheduling an appointment to take a new version of the test or quiz.
One retake per test or quiz is allowed. The adjusted score on the original version will be multiplied by 1/3, the adjusted score on the retake by 2/3, and the two results added together, to a maximum of 83. (Note, however, that Weston High School’s grading policy does not permit carrying over work from one term to the next. Also, retakes will not normally be permitted during the last week of any term, nor after the final exam.)

Grading

Your grade for the quarter will be computed as a weighted average of tests, quizzes, homework, projects, and class participation. Each test will be weighted as 100 points. Quizzes may vary, but will typically be weighted as 40 points or so. In a term with a major project, the project will be weighted as 80 points. Effort and success on class and homework problems may contribute up to 40 points during a quarter.

You will receive a quarter grade of A (or A-) if your overall average is at least 93 (or 90) and your test-and-quiz average is also at least a 90. You will receive a B (with a + or – if appropriate) if your overall average is at least an 80. (Note that this means that an excellent job on homework or a project could be sufficient to raise your grade from, say, a C+ to a B–, or even from an A- to an A, but not from a B+ to an A–.)

The final exam counts as 10%, and each quarter as 22.5%, toward your grade for the year.

Class Participation

Regular attendance is important and is expected of everyone. If you’re absent, you’re still responsible for any material missed! Make up the work ASAP; find out what we did in class by calling a classmate, or by sending email to your teacher, or by seeing your teacher in school as soon as you return. You must make up any missed tests or quizzes right away. If you absolutely must arrive at class late or leave early, do so as rarely as possible.

In addition to your simple presence in class, you are required to participate actively in two different ways. First, of course, you must listen carefully, take the work seriously, do all assigned work in class, and contribute whenever there is group work. Second, you should sometimes volunteer to answer questions or demonstrate solutions. If you do not, you will be called on from time to time anyway.

The most important rule to follow in class is this: First, do no harm. In other words, don’t interfere with your classmates’ ability to learn. The second rule is to commit yourself to a serious attitude and do the work that’s expected of you in and out of class. The third rule is to participate actively in the Honors Precalculus community by helping your classmates learn.

Precalc, Part I
Precalc I

The content of this course includes trigonometry, complex numbers, polynomials, and probability. Students will be expected to become proficient in the application of technology to the study of mathematics. They will use graphing calculators regularly throughout the course and also a variety of computer packages as needed. Applications of mathematics will be emphasized throughout the course. Successful completion of the course will prepare students for a college-level discrete mathematics or precalculus course. In combination with Precalculus, Part Two, with Statistics (Course 352) or with additional summer work, students will be prepared for calculus.

Themes:

  1. Provide students with an appreciation of the importance of mathematics in society by emphasizing mathematical applications and models.

  2. Graphing technology is used to compare the behaviors of functions within different function families.

  3. Transformations are developed as a tool for creating functions with desired properties.

  4. Topics are approached by exploring different representations.


Course Content:

First Quarter: Circle and Triangle Trigonometry

  1. Angles and Their Measure
  2. Unit Circle
  3. Properties and graphs of the Trigonometric Functions
  4. Right Triangle Trigonometry
  5. The Inverse Trigonometric Functions
  6. Trigonometric Equations
  7. Create different representations of trigonometric functions.
  8. Model real world situations with periodic functions.

Second Quarter: Complex Numbers

  1. Introduction of complex numbers
  2. Exploration of fractals using the Julia set and Mandelbrot set.

Third Quarter: Polynomial Functions

  1. Analyze polynomials both graphically and algebraically in order to understand the behaviors of maxima, minima, roots, and long term behavior.
  2. Solve polynomial equations and explore situations that can be modeled using polynomial equations.

Fourth Quarter: Probability

  1. Counting Techniques
  2. Combinations
  3. Permutations
  4. Conditional Probability

table.column: Applied Discrete Math Concepts
App Discrete Math
ADMC

This course offers students who have successfully completed Algebra Two the opportunity to study the application of important mathematical concepts to real world issues and problems. Students will gain a solid understanding of fundamental mathematical ideas by developing mathematical models and applying technology while using these models for decision making. The topics studied might include mathematical models for the study of traffic and the spread of gossip or disease, the use of probability and inferential statistics to make predictions from limited data, applied game theory, mathematical systems for modeling situations ranging from urban geography to political decision making, and numeracy including the history of mankind?s attempts to represent and store numeric data. Students may elect to take the course as a senior elective or as preparation for Course 342.

Applied Discrete Math Concepts (Course 343)

Course Description:

This course is for students who have successfully completed Algebra Two but who are looking for an alternative to the abstraction and heavy symbol manipulation of Pre-Calculus. (The course may also be taken by seniors who have completed Pre-Calculus part 1 but do not wish to complete their precalculus work by taking Pre-Calculus part 2.) The course emphasizes the use of mathematics to model diverse real world situations in order to assist in decision making. Students should leave the course with an appreciation for the power and versatility of mathematics and increased confidence in their ability to apply mathematics.

Themes:

  1. The applicability of a single mathematical model to a variety of situations.
  2. Using mathematical models for decision making in both personal and professional settings.
  3. Acquiring a useful set of mathematical "reference points" for understanding new information (examples: how large is a trillion? how significant is a 1 in 10,000 risk? How reliable are the results of a poll?)
  4. Communicating through mathematics - reading , writing and speaking mathematics.
  5. Reflectiveness as a learner- exploring how one approaches new learning and what aspects assist or impede that learning.

Student Outcomes:

Students will…

  1. demonstrate an understanding that mathematics uses numbers and other symbols to describe abstractions of real world phenomena by using Game Theory to analyze a conflict situation from current events. (Benchmark Assessment)
  2. demonstrate an understanding that a measurement has an implied precision and measures a given attribute by developing a variety of measurements of different magnitudes for the same attribute. (Benchmark Assessment)
  3. improve their ability to assess and compare risks and be aware of some of the psychological factors that influence such assessments.
  4. demonstrate an understanding that mathematical measures can indicate how likely it is that results from a sample will apply to the population at large by using appropriate mathematics to describe the results from a sample poll or experiment. (Benchmark Assessment)
  5. regularly assess their learning and problem solving approaches.
  6. demonstrate their understanding that representing selected parts of available information is an important problem solving tool by using a simulation of an abstract representation of localized behavior to predict global patterns and consequences.

 

Course Content:

Topic 1, Inferential Statistics, uses ideas of probability and sampling to understand confidence intervals and what is meant by the phrase "statistically significant." Students will be able to interpret and evaluate the results of public opinion polls and test each other for evidence of ESP.

Topic 2, Numeracy and Risk Analysis, assists students in acquiring useful references for handling very large and very small quantities and rates. Students will practice estimating quantities by both research and common sense and will combine those estimates to obtain approximate answers to questions such as "How many cans of cat food are opened in New York City in one year?" They will explore various ways of measuring and comparing risks and factors which influence a person's decision to engage in risky behavior. Students will also develop insight into why certain risks are overrated in our society compared to others that are underrated.

Topic 3, Graph Theory, introduces students to important concepts in graph theory such as Eulerian Paths and Hamiltonian Paths, graph coloring and the four color theorem. Students will learn how graph theory can model social networks, the spread of disease, as well as the structure of corporations. The attributes of each graph can have many important implications from the efficiency of interactions to the best way to prevent the spread of disease.

Topic 4, Queueing Theory and Optimization, allows students to develop strategies for modeling different types of lines. Students will learn which queueing discipline is most efficient and how to determine the number of servers needed for different customer frequencies. Students will also learn how to predict the length of a line using Little's Law. Students will also use the Manhattan Metric to optimize efficiency for the location of ambulances, school districting lines, and location of trash collectors.

Topic 5, Game Theory, offers students the opportunity to learn a mathematical model which has wide application to conflict situations. Students will determine payoffs for various strategies and apply algebraic and graphical techniques to determine which strategy or mixture of strategies will yield the best average payoff. Analysis of particular games such as "Chicken" and "the Prisoner's Dilemma" will enable students to discuss the power and limitations of rational analysis when making decisions. The conflict situations discussed will range from analysis of voting procedures to nuclear deterrence, from honor systems to using weather forecasts, from board games to deciding what locations to protect from terrorist attack.

Topic 6, Emergence, explores systems where locally defined behavior applied to a large number of individuals results in surprising patterns on a global scale. Students will use the Net logo computer program to simulate events similar to traffic jams and ant colonies.

 

Materials:

Texts: For All Practical Purposes, written by a committee and published by COMAP (Consortium for Mathematics and Its Applications) sixth edition; Workshop Statistics, written by Rossman, Chance and Oehsen, and published by Key College Publishing; supplemented extensively by teacher-written materials.

Videos/film: COMAP's For All Practical Purposes video and a variety of brief excerpts from movies demonstrating relevant mathematical concepts.

Software: Spreadsheets, graphing software, Internet browsers, and Net Logo are all used in the course.

Calculators: Students are required to use a graphing calculator, preferably the TI-83.

Other Resources: Access to daily newspapers and recent periodicals will assist the student in locating applications of the mathematical decision making techniques being learned.

Course 343

Applied Topics in Precalculus

Supplies

You will need a well-organized notebook. Keep your class notes, homework, handouts and returned quests, problems sets, and projects in it or a folder that you have with you. Developing a system that helps you keep your work organized will be a great support to your learning.

You will also need writing implements, lined and unlined paper, graph paper, and a graphing calculator. You may use any graphing calculator, but the TI-83 (in any of its varieties) is recommended and will be used for class demonstrations. At home you will need a ruler, but we'll provide one if you need it in the classroom.

You will need to do certain assignments on a computer with Internet access. If one is not available at home, be sure to leave time to go to a computer lab at school during or after the school day. Check the resources page to learn about useful computer programs you can download.

Homework

Homework will be posted on www.westonmath.org.

Your work at home will come in a number of different forms. You will often have a nightly assignment. To participate fully in the coming class and to be prepared for other activities associated with the class, it is essential that you have your completed assignment with you at the beginning of class on the day on which it is due. You must show your work for all problems, even when you are not successful. If you can't solve a problem, record your attempts. Specifically, write down what part of a problem statement or what step in the problem solution process made it difficult for you to go on (i.e., pin down the cause of your stuckness- once you can identify your obstacles, you will have a better chance of overcoming them). Another reason to show all of your work is that it is the process that will be of value to you in your future work: you are extremely unlikely to come across the exact same problem again, so you need to be able to think and to communicate your thoughts about the structure of the problem and how you approached it. Your homework will be a valuable resource for open-notebook quests (see below).

Do your homework carefully and promptly. Include the date, your name, the assignment, and the assignment number. (This sounds trivial, but it isn't. Without assignment numbers, it is difficult or impossible to find earlier assignments when it is necessary to refer to them.) Write the entire problem down, or at least show enough of it so you and the teacher can tell what the problem was!

Doing the reading is imperative. Occasionally you will be asked to read a section prior to its being discussed in class. You must take notes on the reading and record questions which you have at any point while doing your work. Writing and reflecting while reading is an important step toward becoming an independent learner. Focus not only on the basic skills and definitions but also on their application in various situations.

The most valuable problems are those you really work on. Some problems from this course you'll want to try again the next day - indeed, the most effective students spend a part of their homework time revisiting past problems and trying to solve them (or resolve them more efficiently or elegantly) using hints and ideas presented in the last class.

If you work on a problem whose answer is in the back of the book, please check it (this is not cheating! It is part of doing your homework) and show a second attempt for incorrect solutions. For problems without answers, consider how you can assess the correctness of your work. You should come to class with specific questions about problems.

Homework, class notes, etc. may be written in pen. The benefit of using a pen is that you do not erase work that may turn out to be worthwhile- that is, you keep a complete record of your thinking. If you think work is incorrect, please put a single diagonal line through it and try again (do not annihilate it).

Tests

Tests may not be announced in advance. This practice encourages you to remain up-to-date in your work and actively and promptly seeking help addressing any questions that you may have about a topic. All tests will be cumulative. Tests will be open notebook except for ideas that are sufficiently central to your learning that you have been given notice to memorize them. An organized notebook with good notes that is with you in class will serve you well.

Problem Sets

During each unit, you will receive a series of problem sets (approximately one per 8 day cycle). You will work on a problem set both in class and at home. Problem sets are designed to help you reflect on the ideas that you have been studying, to practice specific skills, and to solve problems that may require repeated efforts. Take the time to read over a problem set the night that you receive it, to identify which questions may take time to resolve, and to give yourself the chance to work on them, take a break, and return to them over a number of days. Unlike an exercise that is solved quickly, such problems give your brain the chance to play with the question during your breaks from it even when you are doing something else (your brain can do more than one thing at a time). You may find that challenges are more successfully faced through short repeated visits than one long attempt.

Problem sets are formal assignments that you will submit. They should be written neatly and with full, clear explanations (even where not explicitly requested). Write the solution for each problem on a separate side of paper and staple all of your pages together.

Class Participation

Because this course focuses on making decisions and connecting mathematics to your own personal and professional life, your creativity, involvement, and openness to exploration is essential to your own and your classmates' learning. Each student's perspectives will enrich the discussions and contribute to the fun and insight we can gain from these topics.

Class will provide you the opportunity to raise questions around issues about which you are curious as well as about ideas that are confusing you. Both types of questions are important and will serve you and your peers. However, there may be problems that are not satisfactorily addressed in class. Please arrange for extra help with your teacher if you are not confident about your understanding of a subject. These chances for individualized attention can make a great difference in how much you benefit from our whole class discussions.

Regular attendance is expected and important. If you are absent, you are still responsible for any material missed. Please make up the work as soon as possible and find out what we did in class by calling a classmate, sending an email to your teacher, or by seeing your teacher in school as soon as you return. Check www.westonmath.org for the homework assignment. You must make up any missed quests right away. If you know that you will be absent for a class or will have to arrive late or leave early due to an appointment or other school activity, please let your teachers know well in advance so that they can help you to stay on track.

Please study the participation rubric so that you are clear about the expectations.

Grading

Your grade for the quarter will be computed as a weighted average of quests and projects (50%), problem sets (40%), and class participation (10%). Quests will be weighted the same, group projects will count as 1.5 quests, and individual projects as 2 quests.

Striving for Understanding and Competence

If you earn a grade lower than a B on a quest, you will have the option to do extra preparation as determined by your teacher and then take a new quest. You will be able to earn up to a grade of B with this second effort. It is your responsibility to come for the extra assignment, to do the work, and to submit it to your teacher for approval. If the work is satisfactory, then a retest will be given during your free time. You should consider coming for extra help, but you may not take the retest on the same day as the help. Retakes must be taken within two weeks of the original quest. Under certain circumstances, your teacher may count work on a subsequent quest as evidence of your progress in lieu of a separate retake.

If your work on a project reveals fundamental misunderstandings with regard to the material, you may be given the opportunity to submit a revised or second version of the project.

Precalc, Part II
Precalc II

This course provides a detailed study of precalculus and discrete mathematics topics. Included in the course are analysis of functions and limits as applied to rational, exponential, and trigonometric functions; recursion and mathematical induction; complex numbers; and polar coordinates. Additional work may be done in logic, combinatorics, and with the concept of derivatives and integrals. Successful completion of this course will provide a strong background for college-level work in calculus and other mathematics related courses in engineering and science programs.

Course Description

Precalculus, Part Two, is a combination of two one semester courses. The first semester is an introduction to calculus, and the second semester is an introduction to inferential statistics. Most students will take both semesters; however, those who are concurrently enrolled in AP Statistics will take only the first semester (introduction to calculus). Successful completion of this course will provide a strong background for college level work in either calculus or statistics as well as and other mathematics related courses in engineering and science programs.

First Semester Themes:


  • Sequences, Series, and Limits

  • Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change

  • The Derivative

  • Areas Under a Curve and the Integral

    • Second Semester Themes:


  • Describing Distributions

  • Densities and Normal Distributions

  • Sampling Distributions and Estimation

  • Hypothesis Testing

    • Student Outcomes Semester One:

    Students will:

  • 1. Learn how to identify different types of sequences, such as linear, exponential, and quadratic.
  • 2. Learn how to find the sum of a finite number of terms from an arithmetic or a geometric sequence, and how to find the sum of an infinite number of terms from a geometric sequence.
  • 3. Learn how to determine the limits of sequences, series, and rational functions, if such limits exist.
  • 4. Learn how to calculate average rates of change for functions over varying intervals.
  • 5. Learn how to use a limiting process to move from average rates of change to instantaneous rates of change.
  • 6. Become familiar with the idea of a derivative function and the relationship of this function to the instantaneous rate of change.
  • 7. Learn how to calculate the area under a curve through a limiting process, and become familiar with the relationship of the area to the concept of the definite integral.

    • Student Outcomes Semester Two:

    Students will:

  • 1. Explore the concept of random sampling to a variety of different populations, developing the Central Limit Theorem as a result.
  • 2. Calculate and interpret confidence intervals for a population mean from sample data.
  • 3. Conduct tests of significance for a population mean from sample data.
  • 4. Use the concepts of statistical inference to draw valid conclusions about a certain population.
  • 5. Demonstrate an understanding of sampling distributions and the Central Limit Theorem by analyzing different arguments to determine which are valid. (Benchmark Assessment)

    • Course Content:

    Precalculus2 will consist of two big units: an introduction to calculus, and an introduction to statistical inference. Each of these topics builds on the knowledge you gained in your previous mathematics courses, and requires you to use your current mathematical knowledge on a daily basis. Our goals are to prepare you for college-level work in mathematics (including calculus), as well as to expose you to some of the mathematics you may see (and use) on an everyday basis in many different professions.

    An Introduction to Calculus

    The introduction to calculus unit expands on your knowledge of mathematical functions to introduce ideas which will be critical for your future study of calculus. You will begin by learning the concepts of sequences and series. You will learn how to identify different types of sequences, how to quickly find the sum of a several terms of a given sequence, and how to find the limit of a sequence, if it exists. You will also learn how to use the idea of limit in the context of rational functions.

    Next, you will learn about average rates of change. You will employ a limiting process to find the rate of change at a given moment, called the instantaneous rate of change. You will learn how to represent the instantaneous rate of change in the form of a derivative function. Finally, you will learn a bit about the "reverse" process, using the instantaneous rate of change information to determine the original function in a process known as integration.

    Statistical Inference

    The statistical inference unit will help us understand how we can learn about the world by examining data from samples or subsets of larger populations. For example, can a study of the diets of 400 people tell us whether high-fat diets lead to more heart disease in the population as a whole? A big idea of this unit will be the notion of random sampling. Mathematics will help us understand how much the characteristics of a sample are likely to differ from those of the whole population, and why some samples may be more likely to differ from the population than others. We can use these results to estimate certain characteristics of a population (what proportion of voters favor withdrawing from Iraq?) or to test hypotheses about the world (are 17-year olds more likely to be involved in car accidents than 30-year olds?).

    This course will challenge you to become an independent mathematical thinker: proposing and testing your own conjectures, applying mathematics to new situations, and creating your own models. It will stretch the limits of your mathematical understanding as well as exposing you to the power and beauty of modern mathematics.

    Materials:

    Text - used only in second semester: Statistics, Informed Decisions Using Data, written by Michael Sullivan; other units are all supplemented by material supplied by the teacher.

    Software: Microsoft Excel, Minitab 13, Sampling Distribution SIM program. Calculators: Students are required to use a graphing calculator, preferably the TI-83. Other Resources: Use is made of a variety of reference books and texts, websites, applets, and the like.

Supplies

Since we do not use a textbook in this course, you will need a well-organized 3-ring binder. Keep your class notes, homework, returned tests and quizzes, handouts, and blank (lined and graph) paper in it. Though there may not be official notebook checks during the year, an organized notebook and binder will prove to be a valuable resource at test time and throughout the course of the year.

You will need a TI-84 or TI-83 plus calculator. You should have this calculator with you every class period. While you may use a TI-89 or a TI-Inspire for normal assignments, neither of these calculators will be allowed on tests or quizzes.

College Algebra Reboot

Most of you will take a mathematics course at some point in college. Many colleges now have placement exams designed to put you in the most appropriate college math class. Some of you will take these tests next spring or early next fall. In order to help you do well on these tests, we will be consistently reviewing algebra skills during the course of the year. Many classes will begin with a warm-up algebra review, and we will quiz on these algebra skills about once per cycle. You will usually NOT be permitted to use a calculator on these quizzes. Algebra quizzes will have the same value as any other quiz in determining your grade.

Daily Homework and Problem Sets

Working together on homework assignments is allowed and encouraged. However, each student should be certain that she can do the problem herself before feeling that the assignment is complete.

Problem Sets will be handed out about 1 week before a scheduled test. The problem set will be due on the day of the test. The problem set is primarily designed to be a review and practice exercise to prepare for the test. If a student wishes to retake a test (see section on tests and quizzes below) the problem set will be graded as part of the retake process.

Tests & Quizzes

All tests will be announced well in advance, so you will have time to study. You may not use your notes on tests, but you will usually be permitted a 3 x 5 notecard. You will almost always be allowed to use your calculators, although there will often be calculator-free sections on a test or a quiz. Retakes on tests are allowed if the student has scored below 83 percent on a test. A student who wishes to retake a test must meet with her teacher before the retake to go over the original test and the problem set, and the student must complete any additional review assigned by her teacher. The student's problem set will be graded along with the retake test, and the retake grade will be determined by taking one-third of the problem set grade and adding to it two-thirds of the retake test grade. The maximum score on a retake is 83 percent.

Quizzes will be short tasks given approximately once per week. Quizzes may consist of a new problem, a previously-discussed problem, or a problem assigned for homework. There will be no opportunities to retake quizzes, but the lowest quiz grade or grades will be dropped at the end of the term. The number of quizzes to be dropped will depend on how many quizzes are given in the quarter. If 3 or fewer quizzes are given, none will be dropped. If between 4 and 7 quizzes are given, 1 will be dropped, and if 8 or more quizzes are given, 2 will be dropped. If you are absent for a quiz, that will be considered a "drop" except in special circumstances.

Grading

Your grade will be based on a variety of assessments. The primary modes of assessment will be tests, quizzes, homework, projects, and classroom participation. Other types of assessments include: group work, individual or group presentations, nonroutine experiments, and notebook checks.

The breakdown of how you will be graded each term is as follows (applies at least to the first three quarters): Your grade for the quarter will be computed as a weighted average of tests, quizzes, and class effort. Tests will be worth 50% of the grade, quizzes 35%, and class effort 15%. As projects and other non-routine assessments are assigned, your teacher will inform you whether they will count as tests or quizzes, and how much contribution each will make to your overall term grade.

Due to the nature of the fourth quarter for seniors being much shorter than the rest of the quarters, the grades for fourth quarter may or may not be determined the same way as the rest of the quarters.

Class Participation

Regular attendance is expected and important. If you’re absent, you’re still responsible for any material missed! Make up the work ASAP; find out what we did in class by checking westonmath.org, by calling a classmate, or by sending email to your teacher, or by seeing your teacher in school as soon as you return. If you miss a quiz or a test, you must meet with your teacher the day you return to school to schedule the makeup. If you absolutely must arrive at class late or leave early, do so as rarely as possible.

In terms of participation in the class, RESPECT is key to all aspects of learning. You must respect your fellow classmates, your teacher, as well as yourself. Listen to what others have to say, and add your own insights and comments that will aid in classroom discussion. Have a good sense of humor, but also exercise discretion in your language and behavior. Treat all classroom materials and property with respect.

Most importantly, commit yourself to a serious attitude and do the work that’s expected of you in and out of class. Your success in this course depends on how much effort you are willing to put in. Take initiative for extra help. Help is always available- you just need to ask for it. You are not alone in this venture.

Calc AB

Students in this course will study properties of elementary functions and concepts of calculus (limits, derivatives, integrals, and applications). This course will prepare students to take the Advance Placement Calculus AB examination in May.

WELCOME TO AB CALCULUS

The Course

  • Calculus AB is a course in single-variable calculus that includes techniques and applications of the derivative, techniques and applications of the definite integral, and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
  • It is equivalent to at least a semester of calculus at most colleges and universities, perhaps to a year of calculus at some.
  • Algebraic, numerical, and graphical representations are emphasized throughout the course.
  • Graphing calculators are a necessity in class, on homework, and on the AP Examination. It allows you to appreciate connections and more deeply understand the concepts.

Prerequisites

  • Two years of algebra and a year of geometry
  • A strong grounding in elementary functions - their properties, their graphs, and the algebra of functions. Also the language of functions (domain and range, odd and even, periodic, symmetry, zeros, intercepts, etc.) The values of trigonometric functions at 0, pi/6, pi/4, pi/3, pi/2, and their multiples.
  • A willingness to work both in and out of class.
  • A willingness to collaborate with classmates to foster mutual understanding,

Goals

  1. Students should be able to work with functions represented in a variety of ways: graphical, numerical, analytical, or verbal.
  2. They should understand the connections among these representations.
  3. Students should understand the meaning of the derivative in terms of a rate of change and local linear approximation and should be able to use derivatives to solve a variety of problems.
  4. Students should understand the meaning of the definite integral both as a limit of Riemann sums and as the net accumulation of a rate of change and should be able to use integrals to solve a variety of problems.
  5. Students should understand the relationship between the derivative and the definite integral as expressed in both parts of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
  6. Students should be able to communicate mathematics both orally and in well-written sentences and should be able to explain solutions to problems.
  7. Students should be able to model a written description of a physical situation with a function, a differential equation, or an integral.
  8. Students should be able to use technology to help solve problems, experiment, interpret results, and verify conclusions.
  9. Students should be able to determine the reasonableness of solutions, including sign, size, relative accuracy, and units of measurement.
  10. Students should develop an appreciation of calculus as a coherent body of knowledge and as a human accomplishment.

The topics in this course range from elementary calculus concepts to infinite series and differential equations. This course prepares students to take the Advanced Placement Calculus BC examination in May.

Who should take BC Calculus?

Calculus BC is a two semester course designed to provide students with a strong background in Calculus, enabling the students to succesfully pursue further mathematics courses at the most challenging universities. Students should expect

  • one to one and a half hours of homework on each day that class meets.
  • challenging problems both in class and for homework
  • to use the calculator (TI-83) as a tool for investigation and calculation
  • to use a spreadsheet for occasional problems and at least one project
  • problems on tests that require them to use the ideas of the course in a new way
  • to present their work at the board
Course Content:

Introduction to calculus, absolute value inequalities in one and two variables, function review, parametric equations, polar curves, definition of derivative, definition of limit, limit theorems, trigonometric limits, limits at infinity and infinite limits, horizontal and vertical asymptotes, continuity, the Intermediate Value Theorem, the Extreme Value Theorem, the relationship between continuity and differentiability, differentiation formulas, derivatives of trigonometric functions, the chain rule, implicit differentiation, slope fields.

Higher order derivatives, related rates, linear and quadratic approximation, relative error, Newton?s Method, finding maxima and minima, Rolle?s Theorem and the Mean Value Theorem, applications of the Mean Value Theorem, monotonic functions and the first derivative test, concavity and points of inflection, curve sketching, applied maximum and minimum problems, derivatives of parametrically defined curves, antiderivatives, sigma notation, area under a curve, the definite integral, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, average value of a function, calculating definite integrals, area between curves, volumes by slicing, volumes of solids of revolution, area in polar coordinates, arclength.

Work, inverse functions, the Inverse Function Theorem, the natural logarithm and its derivative, the exponential function and its derivative, general logarithmic and exponential functions, logarithmic differentiation, exponential growth and decay, differential equations, inverse trigonometric functions, L?H?pital?s Rule, integration by parts, reduction formulas, integrating powers of trigonometric functions, trigonometric substitution, integration by partial fractions, by substitution, approximate integration, improper integrals, Euler?s Method

Sequences, series, convergence and divergence of series, geometric series, the harmonic and p-series, alternating series with error bound, tests for convergence and divergence including the n-th term divergence test, integral test with error bound, comparison and limit comparison tests, alternating series convergence test, ratio test and root test, absolute convergence, power series, interval and radius of convergence, Taylor and Maclaurin series, representing functions as power series, Lagrange error bound for Taylor polynomials

TEXTS: Calculus, 5th Edition by James Stewart, published by Brooks/Cole, 2003.

  4. Analyzing the inter-relationships and effectiveness of data structures and algorithms.

Course Content:

Topic 1, Objects, Inheritance, and Recursion: Students learn to create and use simple Java classes including abstract classes and interfaces. Recursion is used to process linked lists. Students study discrete methods for binary storage of integers.

Topic 2, Containers, Sorting and Searching: Students use arrays and ArrayLists to store data and study common algorithms for searching and sorting data. Techniques for file I/O are used. Big-O notation is introduced for comparing algorithms.

Topic 3, Polymorphism, Exception Handling, and Java Linked Lists: Students explore polymorphism and inheritance in greater depth, learn techniques for handling errors, and practice creating their own linked lists.

Topic 4, Advanced Java Data Structures: Students explore trees, hashing, maps, graphs, and other structures and their use in problem solving.

Students need to read program specifications carefully and ask for clarification by proposing examples when specifications are unclear.

Each program and paper assignment is listed along with a â€œcurrent gradeâ€: B indicates competent work that demonstrated understanding of the central concept or skill needed to complete the work. AP Stats

This course covers the statistics syllabus prepared by the College Board and is equivalent to a college-level statistics course. Major topics include descriptive statistics; data collection, sampling, and surveys; probability; and statistical inference including confidence intervals and tests of significance. Students will use graphing calculators with statistical capabilities as well as selected computer statistics software. This is a course for students interested in pursuing areas of study requiring statistical analysis of experiments and those who have high motivation and demonstrated mathematical achievement who are interested in working at the college level. Other students interested in statistics should enroll in Precalculus Part Two (Course 352), where a unit on statistical inference is taught.

Who should take AP Statistics?

Juniors and seniors who are interested in pursuing careers that require statistical analysis of experimental data or survey data (i.e. biology, genetics, social science, psychology, economics, political science and business, etc.) are candidates for this course. As a prerequisite, students must have a strong Algebra II and Precalculus, Part I background.

Technology

Students will

  • use a TI-83 or TI-83 Plus calculator
  • use the MINITAB statistical software, available on the Weston High School computer system
  • use various interactive websites

Course Description:

This course covers the statistics syllabus prepared by the College Board and is equivalent to a college level statistics course. Major topics include descriptive statistics, data collection, sampling and surveys, probability and statistical inference including confidence intervals and tests of significance. Students will use graphing calculators with statistical capabilities as well as selected computer statistics software. This is a course for students interested in pursuing areas of study requiring statistical analysis of experiments, and who have high motivation and demonstrated mathematical achievement. Other students interested in statistics should enroll in Precalculus, Part II (Course 352) where a unit on statistical inference is taught.

Course Content:

There are four major topic areas in AP Statistics: Exploring Data, Research Design, Probability, and Inference.

Exploring Data involves using both numerical and visual techniques to study patterns and departures from those patterns in sets of data. This information is used to assess the quality and usefulness of the data set as well as to develop conjectures about the information contained in the data. Numerical methods include measures of center, spread, and location, as well as correlation and regression coefficients to observe relationships between various measures on the same ?subjects?. Graphical methods include boxplots, stemplots, histograms, and scatterplots. Both numerical and visual methods are used to compare data sets, and special methods for the evaluation of categorical data are employed.

Research Design involves deciding what and how to measure as well as developing a plan to collect reliable data through experiment or survey. Students will learn methods of data collection designed to reduce bias, control for confounding factors, and generate reliable numbers. They will also study the principles of sampling and understand the variation inherent in repeated sampling. Students will construct their own experiments and surveys and carry them out to observe these principles in action.

Probability involves the use of both simulation and probability theory to predict what the distribution of data should look like in a particular situation. It is the tool used to anticipate the distribution of data under certain assumptions, and thus provides the basis for testing whether those assumptions are accurate. The techniques of mathematical probability (including conditional probability) will be studied, as well as the use of simulations to estimate probabilities where theoretical methods are insufficient.

Inference involves drawing conclusions about a population from data on a sample of that population. The students will learn how to construct confidence intervals for a population parameter, as well as how to conduct various tests of significance. In particular, we will cover tests for the value of a mean or proportion, tests for the difference of two means or proportions, tests for the ?goodness-of-fit? of data to a proposed distribution, tests for the independence of two measures, and tests for the slope of the least-squares regression line. Students will learn about the relationship between confidence intervals and hypothesis tests as well. An important area of study will be the choice of an appropriate confidence interval or test for the particular issue to be studied.

Text: Stats: Modeling the World, Bock, Velleman, DeVeaux, Pearson, 2007.

AP Statistics is a college-level course. All students taking AP Statistics are expected to approach the course with the seriousness of purpose and motivation expected of students in a college class. Students who do not exhibit such qualities will be asked to drop the class.

In statistical work, results are rarely obvious or intuitive. Rather, the researcher must explain clearly the kinds of data collected, the analytical methods chosen, and the conclusions drawn. These explanations must be clear and thorough. Work unaccompanied by such explanations is, in general, not acceptable.

Working together on homework assignments is allowed and encouraged. However, each student should be certain that she can do the problem herself before feeling that the assignment is complete.

Quizzes, tests, and projects combine for 90% of a term grade, while class participation and effort account for 10%. All tests have the same value; the total of all quizzes for a term equals one test; project values will be assigned based on the time & effort required for the project (they can vary from between 0.5 tests and 2 tests).

Tests:

Two tests will be given in each of the first 3 quarters. Tests will follow the AP format, with a multiple choice section and a free response section. Students will be allowed to use their calculator and the AP "formula sheet" on all tests. Students will not be allowed notecards or notes in addition to or in lieu of the AP "formula sheet" on any tests. Retakes on tests are allowed if the student has scored below an 83 on the original test. A student who wishes to retake a test must meet with her teacher before the retake to go over the original test and the problem set, and the student must complete any additional review assigned by her teacher. The student's problem set will be graded along with the retake test, and the retake grade will be determined by taking one-third of the problem set grade and adding to it two-thirds of the retake test grade, up to a maximum of 83 percent.

Quizzes:

Quizzes will be short (one question) 20-30 minute tasks given approximately once per cycle. Quizzes may consist of a new problem, a previously-discussed problem, or a problem assigned for homework. Quizzes may not be retaken, but the low quiz grades in each quarter will be dropped, according to the following rule: if there are fewer than 3 quizzes in a term, none will be dropped; from 4 to 6 quizzes, 1 will be dropped; more than 6 quizzes, 2 will be dropped.

When a student is absent from class on the day of a test, the test must be made up within four school days. In the case of an extended illness, adjustments to the time period will be made. If it has not been made up within that period the student will receive a zero for that quiz/test. If a student is absent on the day of a quiz, the student may make up the quiz on the next day he/she is present in class, or the student may elect to have the missed quiz be one of the dropped quizzes for that term.

Problem Sets:

Problem Sets will be handed out about 1 week before a scheduled test. The problem set will be due on the day of the test. The problem set is primarily designed to be a review and practice exercise to prepare for the test. If a student wishes to retake a test (see section on tests and quizzes below) the problem set will be graded as part of the retake process. See the section of tests above.

The AP exam takes place in early May, at the end of the (abbreviated) 4th quarter for seniors, and roughly in the middle of the 4th quarter for all underclass students. As a result of this schedule the course is conducted in a different way in the 4th quarter. For seniors, the following are the main activities in the 4th quarter: (1) completion of the student's independent research project, (2) taking a comprehensive exam, with emphasis on problems involving knowledge from multiple sections of the curriculum, and (3) preparing a review outline of a specific topic and leading the class through some review activities. The underclass students will complete these activities as well, and after the AP exam they will engage in several small projects designed to either deepen their understanding of topics already covered or to introduced new methods of statistical analysis. Fourth-quarter grades will be calculated differently than the grades of the previous 3 quarters, with the exact percentages to be determined by the time devoted to each activity in a given class section.

Semester grades are computed by finding the average of the two quarters that make up the particular semester. The year grade is the average of the four quarters. For seniors, the 4th quarter will be weighted one-half as much as the other 3 quarters.
